question.text: Which of the following is set of homologous organs showing divergent evolution?

options.text: Thorns of bougainvillea and tendrils of cucurbita
Forelimbs of horse and wings of insects
Eyes of octopus and eyes of human
Flippers of whales and flippers of dolphins

solution.text:
Homologous organs: The organs with a similar origin, structure and different functions.

Example I: Pattern of bones of forelimbs in whales, bats, cheetah and human (all mammals) share similarities in anatomical structure (all have a humerus, radius, ulna, carpals, metacarpals and phalanges in their forelimbs) but perform different functions.

Example II: Vertebrate hearts.

Example III: Vertebrate brains.

Example IV: Thorns of bougainvillea and tendrils of cucurbita, where both originate from axillary buds but thorns are protective and tendrils are supportive in function.

Analogous organs: The organs with a dissimilar origin, structure but performs the same functions.

Example I: Wings of butterfly and birds.

Example II: Eyes of the octopus and mammals.

Example III: Flippers of penguins and dolphins.

Example IV: Sweet potato (root modification) and potato (stem modification).
